document.description: What foods can be brought into the US after traveling ... what was about to happen so me and my neighboring seats ... Did you ever work at a fast food restaurant? [moved from ...

HOME > Chowhound > Not About Food Save This Board > Email Print
What foods can be brought into the US after traveling abroad? [moved from Spain/Portugal board]
Do you know where I can find a copy of an updated"no fly list"?
I know that meat is prohibited but what about packaged cheeses or can goods? I've heard that canned olives, for example, are fine and I've brought back liters of oil in plain sight several years ago and had no problems. But I always wonder if there are items that are officially prohibited, like oil, olives and canned goods, but are general allowed in small quantities and if there are items like meat that is never allowed.
Permalink | Reply By mielimato on Aug 30, 2006 03:55 PM Updated on Sep 3, 2006
13 Replies
Here is a link to US Customs for prohibited and restricted items. I have found that it is good to carry a copy of the list because sometimes customs will try to confiscate items that are legal. Which they have the right to do even if the item is legal, but it helps.
http://www.cbp.gov/xp/cgov/travel/vacation/kbyg/prohibited_restricted.xml
Here is a link to USDA-APHIS Travelers Tips for what you can import. At the bottom of the page are lists of approved items.
http://permanent.access.gpo.gov/lps30...
Permalink | Reply By JMF on Aug 30, 2006 04:49 PM re: JMF Thanks! This is exactly what I was looking for.
Permalink | Reply By mielimato on Aug 30, 2006 04:54 PM re: mielimato Just be prepared that the customs people are not really up to date on everything. They may allow some banned stuff and confiscate some allowable. Frustrating as check in anymore.
Permalink | Reply By Candy on Aug 31, 2006 12:43 AM
Try the State Dept.'s website. If you can't find the answer in any of their listed categories, you can e-mail them with your question.
http://www.state.gov
Permalink | Reply By RGR on Aug 30, 2006 04:52 PM
I have not traveled since the latest security crack down but in the past, I've brought back butter, cheese, crackers, cookies, mayonnaise, chocolate, pastries, booze, jelly, paprika, pasta and probably other things too numerous too mention. The only thing that was ever confiscated was a braunschweiger sausage from a German grocery store. Yes, I know it is illegal but gosh darn it, I wanted that sausage for dinner and I was hoping they might be asleep at customs that day. They weren't...
Permalink | Reply By Velma on Aug 31, 2006 02:13 AM re: Velma I just spoke with a friend who returned last week from Paris and she was stopped from bringing packaged store bought cookies on the airplane.
The security person seriously claimed the cookie filling was a banned"liquid".
Permalink | Reply By was_bk on Aug 31, 2006 08:10 PM
Ok, so when I fly down to Mexico, I had some some American beef jerky with me as a snack. I had purchased 2 packs of a national brand jerky at the local Giant grocery store in VA.
When I flew out of Mexico, I still had an unopened pack, but customs would not let me bring it into the country, even though I actually bought it in the states.
Did they screw up or was I legally not allowed to bring my jerky back in?
Permalink | Reply By rcheng on Aug 31, 2006 03:58 AM re: rcheng How would they know where you bought it?
Permalink | Reply By PeterL on Aug 31, 2006 10:21 PM re: PeterL They wouldn't know where I had bought it, however the packaging did say that it was packaged in Texas.
Permalink | Reply By rcheng on Sep 3, 2006 04:48 AM
Meat is the thing they always catch me with and confiscate. Lately, they've even added a special meat warning to the declaration form you fill out on the plane, something about how failing to declare your meat will land you in even more trouble than you will be in if you do declare it. Or something.
I've been caught by the dastardly little beagles they occasionally walk past disembarking passengers. If you've got meat and you see a beagle, you're screwed.
Last month I completely forgot about the meat thing and a friend in Paris had just returned from Spain and loaded me up with some awesome chorizo and ham. An hour before landing, I remembered what was about to happen so me and my neighboring seats had a little ham fest. Delicious, but not really the best setting.
On the other hand, I've heard stories of friend-of-a-friends who've sashayed through customs with 30 pounds of spanish ham in their backpacks.
Permalink | Reply By Chuckles the Clone on Aug 31, 2006 06:51 AM re: Chuckles the Clone I regularly come back from South Africa with biltong in my checked luggage - not a lot, usually 2-3 lbs. So far I haven't been caught but I get very nervous every time I go through customs.
Permalink | Reply By cheryl_h on Aug 31, 2006 07:59 PM
re: Chuckles the Clone I truly did forget that I had canned Haggis in my checked luggage. It had been purchased early in the trip and stashed. I just never gave it another thought and besides it was canned. It wan't caught and confiscated but the friend I bought it for went the next year and bought hers in the duty free shop, also canned but she declared it and they took it away.
Permalink | Reply By Candy on Aug 31, 2006 08:40 PM
I heard a story about a Portuguese couple who got caught coming into the US with a huge stash of linguiça for their Californian relatives. When they were told that carrying in meat was forbidden, the husband reportedly said,"This isn't meat! It's sausage!"
Best policy, I think, is not to say anything to the customs folks unless it's absolutely necessary. Cautionary tale: I bought an apple in the Kyoto airport coming home from Japan. I didn't get around to eating it on the plane, so as I entered the SFO customs area (oh, naive me!), I asked an employee where there was a garbage can to toss it, since you can't legally bring fruit or vegetables into the US. Oh, boy. That set off huge alarms. The customs guy made me&my traveling companion go to a special area to have all of our bags x-rayed and some searched, too. This even though I said quite clearly that the apple was the *only* banned thing we had, and I was looking for a place to throw it away *before* going through customs!!
Permalink | Reply By Kitchen Imp on Sep 1, 2006 04:16 PM
